title: A Student's Guide to the ISRO Scientist/Engineer Exam

main.title: Understanding the ISRO Scientist/Engineer Exam
main.html: The ISRO Centralised Recruitment Board (ICRB) exam for the Scientist/Engineer 'SC' post is one of the most prestigious opportunities for engineering graduates in India. This guide breaks down the recent exam format, syllabus, and preparation strategy to help you succeed.

New Exam Pattern

ISRO recently updated its exam pattern. The written test is now a Paper-Based Test (PBT) with two distinct parts. Candidates must qualify in each part separately.

preparation.title: Syllabus & Preparation Strategy
preparation.html:
ISRO vs. GATE: Key Differences

While the core syllabus is similar to GATE, the approach to preparation must be different:

  • Speed vs. Depth: ISRO provides about one minute per question, rewarding speed and accuracy. GATE provides more time, testing in-depth conceptual knowledge.
  • Question Style: Expect more theoretical, formula-based, and direct application questions in ISRO. Complex, multi-step numericals are less common.
  • Syllabus Coverage: A broad, extensive coverage of all topics is crucial for ISRO. Selective study, which can work for GATE, is risky here.

Understanding Allied Topics

A portion of the technical paper will include questions from 'allied' disciplines. You must prepare for these topics to score well.

interview.title: Interview & Final Selection
interview.html:
The Interview Stage

Based on written test performance, candidates are shortlisted for the interview, typically in a 1:5 ratio (vacancies to candidates). The interview holds 50% weightage in the final selection, making it a critical stage. It is highly technical and focuses on your fundamental understanding of core engineering subjects.

Final Qualifying Criteria

To be considered for the final merit list, candidates must meet minimum qualifying scores in both the written test and the interview.

CategoryWritten Test (Each Part)Interview ScoreFinal Aggregate
Unreserved50%50 / 10060%
Reserved40%40 / 10050%

Important: The written test score is only for shortlisting. The final selection is based 100% on the interview score.
